;一位中国女性在离婚后的“暴力”磨难让她受到了波及

;

;这名住在河南省洛阳市的妇女于 5 月 21 日在社交媒体平台抖音上发布了一段短视频。

;

;视频中，她哭诉自己去前婆家给女儿送礼物时，被前家人暴打。

;

;“他们打我是因为我在抖音上发布了我的离婚文件，让他们丢尽了脸，”她说。

;

;网上一段短发女子的视频显示她的嘴在流血，她说，结果是被被她的两个前公婆“压住打”。

;

;愤怒的女人继续说：“他们两个都打我。我一个人。我只是买了一些东西送给我的女儿。我做错了什么？”

;

;位于中部省份湖北省的网络媒体九派新闻报道称，警方正在调查这起事件。

;

;“我们正在调查警方发言人告诉九拍新闻。

;

;“我们一定会依法办案，事后可能会发布通报。”

;

;根据视频中女子出示的警方报告，该案件最初被归类为“相互殴打”。

;

;该事件的一段视频在多个社交媒体平台上引起了极大关注

;

;在微博上，有关该事件的视频新闻报道获得了近700万的点击量，而在抖音上，多个相关视频也吸引了数万条评论。

;

; 一位网友对这位女士表示同情：“离婚后你们就不是家人了。依法处理！”

;

;但也有人表示：“这只是一方面，还是不要这么快下结论。”

;

;截至5月24日下午，警方及当事人均未对事件作出进一步解释。

; Mon, 29 May 2023 11:20:02 +0800 Japanese anime pop star Mai Mizuhashi skirts nationalism to build Chinese fan base on Ride the Wind reality showhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3222028/japanese-anime-pop-star-mai-mizuhashi-skirts-nationalism-build-chinese-fan-base-ride-wind-reality?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.29 11:00;
;;

;日本歌手登上中国顶级音乐节目后在中国的爆红证明了分析人士表示，尽管国际局势紧张且网络民族主义日益高涨，但中国观众仍能将文化与地缘政治区分开来。

;

;艺名 MARiA 的水桥麻衣是最新一季《乘风破浪》中的爆红明星，一个以女性为中心的真人秀节目，以前称为邀请 30 岁以上的公众人物参加流行偶像形式的比赛。

;

;这位 31 岁的茨城本地人本月早些时候以高- 2016 年热门歌曲“极乐净土”的活力表现，这是一首在日本动漫、漫画和游戏 (ACG) 的中国粉丝中广受欢迎的动漫歌曲。

;

;Mizuhashi 在中国的首次展示受到赞扬和庆祝微博上的网友发表的言论，这是一个经常点燃民族主义情绪的微博网站，尤其是在涉及日本和美国等国家的讨论中。

;

;近年来，中日关系恶化。就在两周前，中国驻日本大使警告东京不要在干涉北京与台北的往来时“被引入火坑”，这引发了东京的抗议。

;

;跨学科媒体学者邹胜表示，在浸会大学任教的他说，尽管中日关系低迷，但日本文化在中国被选择性地接受，而二次元几十年来一直受到好评。

;

;“两国之间的文化交流从未停止过 [尽管政治紧张局势]，”邹说。 “它们是由非国家附属机构发起和维护的，例如民间组织、商业媒体和公民本身。”

;

;最新一季的《乘风破浪》拥有该剧自该剧播出以来最具种族多样性的阵容2020 年开播，参赛选手包括俄罗斯歌手卡捷琳娜·凯利、韩国女演员秋瓷炫、越南女星奇普、德国钢琴家吉娜·爱丽丝·雷德林格和美国歌手安妮·洛德米尔克。

;

;“该节目提供了一个公共或文化外交的场合，这是非官方的，而国家更关注安全、经济和地缘政治问题，”邹说。

;

;他补充说，中国与日本交往的文化和政治层面是“交织在一起，但遵循不同的逻辑”。

;

;邹说，虽然网络民族主义盛行，但中国观众是“异类”的，导致被水桥的艺术或日本亚文化所吸引的人与有政治倾向的人之间几乎没有重叠。

;

;邹说，与许多其他卫星电视作品一样，《乘风破浪》主要是商业投资，但鉴于娱乐是“不可或缺的一部分”，民族主义情绪可能是副产品。

;

; p>;

;“该节目的营销口号是'伟大的美丽中国'，它促进了以中国为中心的世界主义，”邹说。 “我称之为自私的世界主义，因为它旨在将中国与世界的接触描绘成一个负责任的领导者。”

;

;“无法停止观看”：数以百万计的中国人拥抱日本真人秀明星 MARiA

;

;专门研究现代中国媒体、文学和流行文化的文化研究学者曹雪南表示，对水桥的表演出人意料的热烈反响也反映了中国日本二次元粉丝群体的默默无闻。

;

;曹说，水桥的出现标志着以她的音乐和时尚为代表的动漫亚文化罕见地出现在主流电视上。它引起了中国御宅族的共鸣——沉浸在网络动画世界中的青年和中年人。

;

;“中国御宅族有相当多但不可见的观众，他们通常看不到他们喜欢的图像类型在电视上，”曹说。

;

;“水桥的爆红反映了他们一直期盼着这样的时刻，其中很多人都困在中低收入的工作岗位上，对生活持不屑一顾的态度，但想要发泄一下。”

;

;Ride the Wind 刻意宣传的名人选手符合女性的特定形象——有力量、独立且拥有强大的人格，但这无法服务于一部分寻求女性的观众。据香港中文大学助理教授曹说，“另类女性形象”，例如水桥。

;

;“主流媒体期望加强的文化价值观之间存在差距就如何在一个有很多人的社会中成为一个衰老和/或单身女性而言，与想要强化相反的观众的实际品味相比，”曹说。

;

;“观众想要一种不同类型的女性，是男性凝视或御宅族凝视的发明，”曹说，他将“可爱的”水桥与 2021 年赢得该节目的 55 岁中国歌手那英进行了比较并且以直率和阳刚的性格而闻名。

;

;“由于她在商业上的成功，现在人们关注的是中国观众在多大程度上[吸收]了日本亚文化，”曹说，并补充说不同世代的中国观众对这位动漫明星的表演会有不同的反应。她说年长的观众可能会认为它“有毒”。

;

;什么是异世界？日本动漫类型的人气暴增

;

;随着中国制作寻求超越国界并创造国际观众，以及越来越多的观众对屏幕上的多样性持开放态度，无论地缘政治紧张局势如何，这一趋势都将持续下去，分析师对此表示同意，同时补充说来访的艺术家可能也有同感。

;

;“外国名人及其公司非常清楚中国拥有更大的市场，因此他们的主要动机是利用这一市场并培养他们的粉丝基地——只要它不与政治纠缠在一起，”邹说。

; Mon, 29 May 2023 11:20:02 +0800 Korean women reject K-beauty standards in ‘Escape the Corset’ revolthttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/3222131/korean-women-reject-k-beauty-standards-escape-corset-revolt?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.29 11:01;
;;

;在世界美容之都首尔，外科医生提供最近的大学甚至高学校毕业生在手续上享有折扣，以便他们为就业市场做好准备；在韩国，简历通常要求求职者附上照片，以及体重和身高。

;

;三分之一的 19 至 39 岁韩国女性做过某种整容手术，据称根据 2020 年盖洛普韩国民意调查——66% 的人表示他们会接受手术以提高在婚姻市场上的机会。更令人沮丧的是，多芬品牌 2007 年的一项调查发现，四分之一的韩国母亲建议 12 至 16 岁的女儿接受手术。

;

;然而，一些韩国女性已经受够了。< /p>;

;自 2018 年以来，数十万人在社交媒体上发布了自己剪长发和卸妆的照片。他们穿着宽松的衣服和眼镜冲上街头。

;

;他们称他们的运动为“摆脱紧身胸衣”。

;

;“我将其描述为反对这种[审美]劳动的总罢工Elise Hu 说，她的新书《完美无瑕：来自 K-Beauty Capital 的外貌和文化教训》审视了价值 100 亿美元的韩国美容行业。

;

;胡为这本书采访的女权主义者报告说，她们每个月在护肤品上的花费在 500 美元到 700 美元之间。他们中的一些人记录了他们每天花在打扮自己以准备出现在公众面前的时间。

;

;胡说，在放弃化妆、护肤品和美容治疗后，“他们解放了很多时间和精力，这是不可忽视的，因为它是我们自由的重要杠杆。”

;

;为什么韩国的防晒霜这么好，比美国的好吗？

;

;经济和财政部的消费数据显示，20 多岁的韩国女性与美容相关的支出实际上已经下降，而且她们接受整形手术的次数也在减少，胡写道。

;

;“这就像第二次-在美国掀起女权主义浪潮，燃烧胸罩，”胡说。 “韩国的女权主义者是世界上最有组织、最令人印象深刻、最杰出的女权主义者之一。他们应该得到更多的关注。”

;

;在韩国，美丽不仅仅是肤浅的。这是一种责任。

;

;“满足最低限度的外表只是礼貌，”胡解释道。 “如果你为了融入社会而接受整容手术，你不仅仅是为了自己好看——这也是对社区中其他人的尊重。”

;

;政府通过保留美容产品和治疗的成本很低，甚至可以为希望融入新家园的朝鲜难民提供无偿整容手术。

;

;但是，尽管这种“自我保健消费主义”可以成为一些人赋权的源泉– 允许女性，有时是男性，跨越阶级界限 – 这也会产生破坏性后果。

;

;“当你说你的身体可以改变，你可以看起来更好时，你最终会被评判因为没有对你的外表做任何事情，”胡说。 “那真的很危险。”

;

;胡于 2015 年从美国移居首尔，担任 NPR 的国际记者。随即，她被“作为一名女性在城市和空间中穿梭的感觉是多么不平等”而震惊，她说。陌生人评论她的雀斑——“你知道有办法去除这些雀斑吗？” – 以及她的“大号”。

;

;Hu 以前是目录模特，通常穿着美国 8 码的连衣裙，不得不去一家专门的商店购买更大的身材。她说，韩国只有一种尺码——“自由”尺码——相当于美国的 0 号或 2 号。

;

;但她见证了行动主义和社会清算时刻带来的缓慢、稳定的变化。< /p>;

;官员们表示，韩国首都首尔将限制在公共交通工具上使用整形手术广告，此前有人抱怨这些广告助长了对身体形象的不健康痴迷。

;

;2016 年一名男子在江南地铁站附近谋杀了一名年轻女子，因为他说他觉得自己被异性“贬低”了。在接下来的几天里，成群结队的愤怒、受够了的女性涌入地铁站。

;

;是什么推动了韩国的“精液恐怖主义”和日本的乱伦暴力？

;

;“她们只是出现了并在这些五颜六色的便利贴上贴满了诸如‘我只是偶然逃脱’或‘这可能是我’之类的信息，”胡回忆道。 “那种真正开始了女权主义的大浪潮，我在 2010 年代中期在韩国的时候亲眼目睹了这一点。”

;

;“然后#MeToo 发生在第二年，导致罢免很多著名的韩国男性，然后女性在一个历史上一直是重男轻女的国家找到了自己的声音。”

;

;逃离紧身胸衣就是从这个时刻开始的。

;

;“基本上韩国女性就像，我已经受够了这些非常紧身的铅笔裙，还有我们应该拥有的长而奢华的头发，还有完美的皮肤，而且总是化妆，”胡说。 “所以他们就在社交媒体上剪了头发，压碎了化妆盒，统计了他们为保持形象所花费的时间和金钱，然后出示了这些收据 [并宣布] 他们不会去

;

;一份关于东亚性别研究的学术期刊发表的关于韩国妇女运动的报告称，“脱节紧身胸衣”运动的参与者人数为 30 万人。他们为自己的自主权放弃了很多。超过 56% 的韩国男性表示，如果女朋友说她是女权主义者，他们会与她分手。

;

;“这太疯狂了，”胡说。 “他们真的牺牲了家庭关系，因为他们会不请自来地参加聚会。他们牺牲了职业友情，他们牺牲了招聘，可能是为了工作而被聘用。”

;

;“上周末有一位老师跟我说，她的学生经常问她为什么不穿衣服她的头发留长 [或] 早上准备好，”她说。

;

;“这些都是小学生。 [他们]告诉她，她的父母说她很懒惰，因为她不努力工作。这就是问题所在，当我们将美貌视为个人责任时。”

;

;深浅不一：亚洲嘻哈音乐为皮肤美容定下新基调

;

;In所有，胡说她仍然充满希望：对于韩国的女性，对于世界上的女性，对于我们这些试图反抗一个告诉我们外表就是一切的社会的人。

;

;“我觉得就像谈论这本书一样，”她说，“现在正在发生很多可能不存在的认识，或者在 10 年前的谈话中。”

;

From pre-fab buildings to buses, businesses seek deals in regionhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3222093/3-months-after-john-lees-visit-saudi-arabia-have-hong-kong-firms-made-inroads-pre-fab-buildings?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;香港建筑事务所 Leigh & Orange 即将确认香港的主要项目中东，得益于其在该市设计预制 Covid-19 检疫设施的经验。

;

;董事总经理 Ivy Lee Siu-wing 告诉邮报，该公司最近在中东完成了两笔“多方面的超级项目”交易沙特阿拉伯，并正处于在卡塔尔达成合作的最后阶段。

;

;她的公司是开始收获行政长官李家超对沙特的高层访问成果的香港企业之一阿拉伯和阿拉伯联合酋长国 (UAE)，2 月。

;

;利安 (Leigh & Orange) 是在大流行期间通过使用模块化集成构造 (MiC) 方法建造 Covid-19 隔离装置的香港公司之一

;

;2021年在香港科学园建造InnoCell也采用该方法，仅用71天将418个预制模块组装成17层楼的宿舍，缩短传统建筑时间缩短了 40%。

;

;“除了中国大陆，没有其他地方以这种速度完成过这种规模的项目。这是一个强有力的保证，我们不会兜售可能会或可能不会成功的梦想，”她说。

;

;香港的 John Lee 结束了在沙特阿拉伯的技术会议

;

;Lee，他作为香港代表团的一员，她的公司跟进了海湾国家的同行，为那里的发展项目提供了创新的解决方案。

;

;其中包括建立“临时城市”，这在亚洲是独一无二的中东每年举办大型临时宗教和商业活动。

;

;“这就是中东所需要的。他们缺乏高技能的建筑工人，但要求快速完成工作。他们希望在现场有 5,000 名工人，而质量无法得到保证。”

;

;在访问期间，签署了 13 份谅解备忘录，其中一份由香港巴士营运商与沙特阿拉伯的巴士营运商签署最大的私营企业集团 Nesma Holding。

;

;New World First Bus 和 Citybus 在香港的 200 条路线上运营着 1,700 辆巴士，去年合并并通过 Bravo Transport 由香港另类投资公司 Templewater 拥有服务。 Templewater 还收购了制造该市第一辆电动双层巴士的 Wisdom Motor。

;

;香港与沙特阿拉伯签署 6 项协议，Lee 誓言“合作新水平”

;

;Templewater 主席和首席执行官 Cliff Zhang Kun 表示，正在就使用零排放车辆技术升级沙特阿拉伯的公交车队并重新设计其公交线路以缓解交通拥堵进行谈判。

;

;他表示，公司可以帮助其合作伙伴提高效率。

;

;“他们希望通过许多大型项目来促进旅游业，因此需要一个高效且管理良好的公交网络，”他说。

;

;Wisdom Motor 也是他说，考虑在中东建立生产设施。

;

;John Lee 飞往中东和东南亚，香港没有解决办法：专家

;

;沙特首都利雅得的通勤者目前严重依赖私家车和网约车服务。其公交服务的第一阶段，在 15 条路线上有 340 辆公交车，上个月才启动并正在扩大。

;

;在该市拥有 85 个车站的地铁网络和一家新的国家航空公司利雅得航空公司，王储穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼 (Mohammed bin Salman) 领导的沙特 2030 年愿景计划也在规划中。

;

;同为香港代表团成员的张说，现在是香港公司开辟自己的利基市场的好时机

;

;中国和沙特阿拉伯在习近平访问期间签署了 34 项能源和投资协议

;

;中国国家主席习近平去年访问利雅得两国同意加强伙伴关系以超越石油并深化跨行业协调，标志着建立新的贸易关系。

;

;香港与海湾合作委员会成员国——沙特阿拉伯、阿联酋、巴林之间的商品贸易总额、科威特、阿曼和卡塔尔——到 2020 年达到 1000 亿港元（130 亿美元）。

;

;中国正寻求将自己定位为美国的替代安全伙伴，因为它专家表示，中国越来越多地开展“军事外交”，在该地区开展涉及东南亚国家的联合演习。

;

;本月，中国和老挝举行了“友谊之盾 2023”演习，其中涉及一系列武器装备、作战训练和支持行动。中新海上合作演习也在新加坡海域举行，两国在新加坡海域进行了海上反水雷和实弹射击演习。

;

;4月，中越海警在新加坡海域进行了联合巡逻。北部湾，而中国和柬埔寨举行了“金龙 2023”联合演习，其中包括应对模拟恐怖袭击的实弹演习。

;

;民族主义小报《环球时报》援引中国军事专家傅前哨的话说， “在美国一直在该地区挑起事端的时候”，中国将继续加强与东南亚国家的关系，以营造一个和平稳定的环境。

;

;这个问题很可能会在本周末在新加坡举行的香格里拉对话，与亚太地区安全息息相关的国防大臣和政策制定者将出席。

;

;美国海军战争学院教授保罗·J·史密斯以个人身份接受《亚洲周刊》采访的他将增加的联合演习描述为试图恢复到大流行前的行动水平，这也是为了回应中国认为美国及其盟友的强硬行动。

;

;在最近于印度尼西亚举行的 G7 峰会上，美国、日本及其西方盟友就他们对北京日益增长的担忧以及遏制中国的方式发表了同声传译。

;

;“趋势在 [中国国家主席] 习近平的领导下取得了进步，”史密斯说，并指出北京将“军事外交”视为“其整体国际外交剧本的核心原则”。

;

;G7 ‘把头埋在沙子里’气候变化与“临时”天然气投资

;

;然而，史密斯说，由于其“偶发性和装饰性”的性质，中国与东南亚同行的钻探价值“有限”，并补充说这在很大程度上还取决于

;

;“如果中国部署其不太先进或不复杂的平台，则表明这种接触是有限的，并且仅出于外交或公共关系目的进行，”史密斯说，并指出军事外交不能忽视“曝光”和“信号”。

;

;“曝光”是指在演习期间发布有关平台、能力或操作规范的关键数据。

;

; p>;

;例如，如果中国或任何参与国发送先进设备，它将传输有关该平台或操作程序的敏感信息，而这可能出于“威慑、外交劝说 [even ] 未来武器销售的营销”，史密斯说。

;

;“信号”是指有意或无意地传达有关演习目的的信息，无论是为了产生善意还是“向第三国发送信息”或国际社会”，史密斯说，并补充说中国可能会增加在该地区进行此类演习的频率，以此作为打破它认为美国遏制的一种方式。

;

;Blake Herzinger，研究悉尼大学美国研究中心研究员表示，虽然中国曾试图将自己定位为替代安全伙伴，但最近的演习并未反映出新的动态，因为柬埔寨和老挝等国家“已经更多地落入北京的轨道” ...作为新加坡，赫辛格表示，与中国保持积极关系包括“低级别的防御接触”，由于该岛国与美国的“更重要的安全关系”，这种接触不太可能进一步发展。

;

;“低- Herzinger 说，“水平熟悉演习”有助于在中国与东南亚军队之间建立一定程度的了解，“这可能有助于避免更大的问题”，但“再多的建立信任措施也无法抵消”中国破坏其邻国主权的持续努力.

;

;“总的来说，鉴于北京与邻国的争端和欺凌行为的历史，北京不是该地区可靠的安全伙伴，”赫辛格说，他指的是中国与东南亚国家之间的领土争端，以及北京对地区船只的骚扰，例如上个月在南中国海拦截菲律宾巡逻艇。

;

;几十年来，该地区的国家一直在与其地区和西方同行进行训练。菲律宾和美国举行“肩并肩作战”军演，而泰国与华盛顿一起为亚太地区的军队举办“金色眼镜蛇”军事演习。

;

;菲律宾-美国军演以增强外部防御和网络安全能力

;

;新加坡和马来西亚也参加了与澳大利亚、新西兰和英国的五国防御安排演习。本月，新加坡军方还与美国军方在夏威夷举行了 2023 年第 42 次万金油演习。

;

;近年来，日本和法国等国家也与该地区进行了联合演习；东京与越南进行了友好演习，与菲律宾进行了人道主义援助和救灾训练，并于去年首次参加了美国和印度尼西亚联合演习的鹰航盾牌演习。

;

;法国和印度尼西亚陆军和海军在 3 月进行了两次单独的联合演习，而在 2021 年，法国和新加坡海军在南中国海南部进行了一次演习。

;

;让-马蒂厄·雷伊，法国海军上将兼总统海军对外关系部部长表示，作为“全球主权的提供者和美国最古老的盟友，巴黎“与志同道合的国家发展伙伴关系”以确保“自由开放的印太地区、多边主义和尊重国际法律”。

;

;Herzinger 说，东南亚国家应该决定它们的国家利益和最适合它们需要的安全关系类型。

;

;“对于大多数人来说，平衡与华盛顿和北京将是必要的，有些国家更倾向于一边而不是另一边，”他说，并指出美国的训练将“仍然是黄金标准”。

;

;并指出东盟国家转向这些联合训练澳大利亚国立大学博士生 Abdul Rahman Yaacob 表示，与中国的演习是“他们对冲战略的一部分”，中国在该地区扩大军事演习规模和范围的长期能力取决于北京是否升级了紧张局势南中国海。

;

;“一些东盟国家内部将面临压力，不要与中国建立更密切的防务关系，”他说，并补充说，由于该地区国家依赖美国的武器，华盛顿可能不赞成在与中国的联合演习中部署美国武器平台。

;

;“例如，我们不太可能看到新加坡的 F-35B 战斗机参加与中国空军的联合演习，”阿卜杜勒·拉赫曼说, adding that joint military exercises with the US were more complex, involving close coordination, command and control, and a high level of interoperability.

;

;Principally funded by the US, the F-35B is said to be the world's most advanced fighter jet, able to perform both air superiority and strike missions, while providing electronic warfare and intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance capabilities.

;

;Singapore announced in February that it would acquire another eight F-35B jets from US manufacturer Lockheed Martin, growing its fleet of the fifth-generation fighters to 12.

;

;Collin Koh, a research fellow at the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies in Singapore, said that while the exercises provided regional militaries with an insight into how the People's Liberation Army worked and its latest capabilities, they did not add as much value in “furnishing new operational insights and building interoperability”, something which could only be gained by participating in exercises with extra-regional counterparts.< /p>;

;South China Sea: Vietnam demands Chinese ship leave its zone

;

;Koh added that the drills also helped promote the idea of inclusivity of Association of Southeast Asian Nations in the regional architecture.

;“By engaging China in these exercises, they also facilitate the People's Liberation Army's participation in broader Asean-wide military exercises such as those under ARF and ADMM+,” Koh said, referring to the Asean Regional Forum, a platform for security dialogue in the region, and the Asean Defence Ministers' Meeting Plus, a channel connecting Asean and its eight dialogue partners Australia, China, India, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, Russia and the US.

;Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings said on Monday it had cut compensation for the team that recommended its investment in the now-bankrupt FTX cryptocurrency exchange, as well as for its senior management team.

;The move comes around six months after Temasek initiated an internal review of its investment in FTX, which resulted in a writedown of US$275 million.

;“Although there was no misconduct by the investment team in reaching their investment recommendation, the investment team and senior management, who are ultimately responsible for investment decisions made, took collective accountability and had their compensation reduced,” Temasek Chairman Lim Boon Heng said in a statement posted on Temasek's website on Monday.

;

;FTX's other backers such as SoftBank Group Corp's Vision Fund and Sequoia Capital had also marked down their investment to zero after FTX, founded by Sam Bankman Fried, filed for bankruptcy protection in the US last year.

;

;“With FTX, as alleged by prosecutors and as admitted by key executives at FTX and its affiliates, there was fraudulent conduct intentionally hidden from investors, including Temasek,” Lim said in the statement on Monday. “Nevertheless, we are disappointed with the outcome of our investment, and the negative impact on our reputation.”

;;2023.05.29 09:00;
;;

;Hong Kong has succeeded in recruiting dozens of internationally recognised academics to its universities in recent months, but some said limited laboratory space and lack of modern equipment, as well as high rents, could deter others from opting for the city.

;

;David Parker, 66, became chair professor of chemistry at Baptist University (HKBU) in September last year after a distinguished career at the prestigious Durham University in Britain.

;

;Parker, who earned his doctorate from the prestigious Oxford University, told the Post that HKBU had attracted him to Hong Kong.

;

;“Notably, HKBU chemistry relates to building a community of creative and talented people who can work together in interdisciplinary research,” he said.

;

;The recipient of numerous honours in the UK, Parker is a Fellow of the Royal Society and was also awarded the Royal Society of Chemistry (RSC) Tilden Lectureship and silver medal, as well as the RSC Ludwig Mond Medal for inorganic chemistry.

;

;The scientist was taken on under a government-funded programme designed to lure international talent in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) to Hong Kong – the Global STEM Professorship Scheme.

;

;But, after working for about nine months as the director of the Jockey Club STEM Laboratory and Global STEM chair professor at HKBU, he said that the lab facilities in Hong Kong institutions were not up to the job.

;

;“Hong Kong does not compare favourably with mainland China, Europe or the US in the provision of high-quality laboratory research space,” Parker said.

;

;“There is an acute shortage of modern research lab space for the chemical and biological sciences.”

;

;HKUST starts global scheme to attract top academics to Hong Kong for research

;

;Parker added: “Many university labs are overcrowded and lack sufficient key facilities like fume cupboards or controlled temperature and humidity labs.

;

;“There is an unmet and pressing need for the government to launch a modernisation programme through grants for the construction of such facilities, notwithstanding the pressure on space in many university science and engineering departments.”

;

;However, the scientist said he had benefited from multimillion-dollar funding through a grant scheme run by the Hong Kong Jockey Club Charities Trust to help buy equipment, computer hardware and software needed to help set up a new research laboratory.

;

;There were 39 academics on the Hong Kong programme in March, with Polytechnic University (PolyU) home to about a quarter of them. About 15 per cent are from overseas and the rest are from the mainland, with experience of study and work in Western countries.

;

;The Education Bureau has told lawmakers that every STEM academic recruited under the scheme could apply for funding to hire up to four researchers to help in research work.

;

;Takashi Hibiki, 60, a professor in mechanical engineering from Japan, was recruited by City University (CityU) under the government programme in 2021.

;

;Hibiki, who spent 16 years at Kyoto University in Japan and 12 years at Purdue University in the US, agreed insufficient lab space could be a problem.

;

;“If we have to conduct demonstration research that requires the use of relatively large experimental equipment, lab space can be a major issue,” he said. “Fortunately, CityU provides sufficient lab space for me.”

;

;He also praised government and university support, which allowed him to have the hardware and software he needed.

;

;Hibiki, an American Nuclear Society Fellow, an Osaka University Global Alumni Fellow and a Fellow of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, said he first came to Hong Kong after he was invited to give a lecture at CityU in 2019.

;

;“It was a conversation with the then CityU president Way Kuo that led me to decide to accept the offer from Hong Kong. Kuo was passionate about higher education,” he explained.

;

;Hibiki added that Hong Kong made it easy to contribute to education and research in the countries because of its strategic location.

;

;Professors from other countries also highlighted a problem shared with other sectors – the high cost of accommodation.

;

;Chen Qingyan, 64, who has worked as a director at PolyU's Academy for Interdisciplinary Research since 2021 after he was also recruited under the STEM scheme, said housing prices and tenant regulation made it difficult to call Hong Kong his home and he doubted he would stay long-term.

;

;“The housing condition is really a big issue. In my life, I've always lived in my own apartment, our own house,” he said. “Purchasing a property in Hong Kong is an unrealistic dream.”

;

;Chen has worked at top US universities, including the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), for a quarter of a century and has also held posts in the Netherlands and Switzerland.

;

;Mainland Chinese academics outnumber locals at Hong Kong universities for first time

;

;He rents a flat in Hung Hom, but added the landlord could ask him to leave with one month's notice.

;

;Parker agreed the cost of living was a deterrent for academics in Hong Kong.

;

;“One key issue in attracting these people is the cost and nature of accommodation,” he said.

;

;Parker also highlighted a shortage of trained personnel at technical, PhD and postdoctoral levels.

;

;“We need to attract more international researchers to come to Hong Kong, to train them well and help realise the potential that Hong Kong is capable of for innovative STEM research,” he said.

;

;Public universities also recruit talent through their own programmes.

;

;Chinese researchers in US 'eyeing medical teaching jobs at University of Hong Kong'

;

;A spokesman for the University of Hong Kong said its “Global Professoriate Recruitment Campaign”, launched in November 2020, had netted 44 distinguished academics from prestigious universities such as Stanford, Princeton, Yale and MIT.

;

;The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology said it had recently launched its “30 for 30” Talent Acquisition Campaign to recruit 30 senior academics across six strategic areas covering biomedical science, artificial intelligence, sustainability and green technology.

;

;Meanwhile, Chinese University noted it had added about 100 new non-local academics, including assistant professors and associate professors, each year between 2020 to 2022 under the government scheme or its own recruitment programme.

;Chinese scientists who have turned hard silicon solar cells into an elastic form as thin and soft as paper say their breakthrough technology has broad applications in aerospace, wearable electronics and portable power sources.

;

;Over the past few years, advances in materials and manufacturing have led to impressive gains in the efficiency of silicon solar cells. They now boast a light-electricity conversion rate of 26.8 per cent – approaching the theoretical limit of 29.4 per cent.

;

;Silicon solar cells represent about 95 per cent of the solar cells used in the photovoltaic market. They have been widely used in ground-based solar farms and distributed photovoltaics since manufacturing and power generation costs came down.

;

;But developing commercially viable and highly efficient solar cells that are lightweight, flexible and low cost – and that can be used on a large scale – is a challenge.

;

;Thin-film solar cells currently in use are made from amorphous silicon, cadmium telluride, organics and perovskites.

;

;They do “exhibit flexibility”, according to Liu Wenzhu, a professor at the new energy technology centre of the Chinese Academy of Sciences' Shanghai Institute of Microsystem and Information Technology (SIMIT).

;

;“But their use is limited because of their low power conversion efficiency … the release of toxic materials into the environment, inferior performance in the case of large areas and unstable operating conditions,” Liu said.

;

;His team has come up with an innovative structure for silicon solar cells to make them flexible – and they say the study suggests mass production is also viable.

;

;The scientists – from SIMIT, the Changsha University of Science and Technology and the Saudi Arabian Oil Company – published their study findings in the peer-reviewed journal Nature on May 24.

;

;The development could open up new opportunities in sectors like wearable electronics, mobile communications, mobile energy for vehicles, integrated photovoltaics in architecture, and in aerospace.

;

;As new entrants eye China solar sector, overcapacity and price war concerns mount

;

;The team began by observing silicon solar cells placed under bending stress using high-speed cameras. They found that cracking always began at a sharp V-shaped groove at the edge of the silicon wafer – an area they defined as its “weak point”.

;

;“Understanding the fracturing behaviour of solar cells led us to alter the structure of the silicon wafer's edge area. We replaced the sharp 'V' grooves with smoother 'U' grooves, which effectively distribute the bending strain and suppress the fracturing behaviour,” Di Zengfeng, corresponding author of the study, said in a report on SIMIT's website on Wednesday. “The final result is a highly efficient, lightweight and flexible silicon solar cell.”

;

;That strategy was only used at the edge of the wafer, so it does not have an impact on the power conversion efficiency of the solar cell, Liu Zhengxin, another corresponding author, said in the report.

;

;“However, it does significantly increase the solar cell's flexibility, which offers broad application prospects,” he said.

;

;The silicon solar cell has unprecedented flexibility, according to the paper. Measuring 60 micrometres, it can be folded like a sheet of paper. It can also withstand repeated bending, with a bend radius of less than 5 millimetres and bend angles exceeding 360 degrees.

;

;The researchers also conducted durability testing under different conditions. The cells retained 100 per cent of their power conversion efficiency after 1,000 side-to-side bending cycles. They also retained 99.62 per cent of their power after thermal cycling between minus 70 degrees Celsius (minus 94 Fahrenheit) and 85 degrees Celsius (185 Fahrenheit) for 120 hours.

;

;Has a Chinese-Swiss team cracked the code for making solar energy cheaper?

;

;In a wind resistance test, researchers attached a cell module to an inflated gasbag and used a powerful fan to model the effect of wind blowing at a speed of 30 metres per second during a violent storm. After continuous air impact for 20 minutes, the relative power loss was only 3.07 per cent, suggesting its potential use in aerospace, such as spy balloons.

;

;According to the report, the research team's large-area flexible photovoltaic modules have already been successfully used in near-space vehicles, integrated building photovoltaics, and vehicle-mounted photovoltaics.

;

;But the team remain cautious about the manufacturing technology. “More in situ tests need to be performed before large-scale production to guarantee consistent stability under real-life operating conditions where stressors may occur simultaneously,” Liu Wenzhu said in the paper.

;Chinese Quora-like question-and-answer service Zhihu has developed a new search function that completes tasks using an artificial intelligence (AI) algorithm, similar to the content-generating technology behind US start-up OpenAI's ChatGPT.

;

;Zhihu, China's biggest knowledge-sharing platform operator, will immediately start its internal test of the function called Sousuo Juhe, which translates to “search aggregation” in English, according to company chief technology officer Li Dahai, who was cited in a report on Saturday by state-backed newspaper Science and Technology Daily.

;

;Acting on a user's search for a specific topic, the new feature would extract and compile user-generated answers to offer a comprehensive result, which “improves the efficiency in accessing information”, the report said.

;

;Zhihu uses a large language model (LLM) that it co-developed with Beijing-based AI start-up ModelBest, in which the New York- and Hong Kong-listed company led a funding round in April.

;

;At that time, Zhihu and ModelBest said they were jointly training the LLM called “Zhihaitu AI” and exploring its application on the trending list section of the Chinese question-and-answer service.

;

;An LLM is a deep-learning algorithm that can recognise, summarise, translate, predict and generate text and other content based on knowledge gained from massive data sets.

;

;ModelBest on Saturday also unveiled its own ChatGPT-like chatbot, named Luca, that is able to draft documents, translate articles and analyse images.

;

;These latest consumer AI developments come days after internet watchdog the Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) warned that advanced technologies such as generative AI – exemplified by chatbot app ChatGPT, which is not available on the mainland – could pose a “serious challenge” to governance, regulation and the labour market in the country.

;

;China's internet watchdog warns of risks from generative AI, other advanced tech

;

;The separate announcements from Zhihu and ModelBest reflect how Chinese tech firms are making the most of AI advances, while walking a fine line to abide by Beijing's efforts to regulate and rein in the rapid development of ChatGPT-like services on the mainland.

;

;Online search provider Baidu, e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding, AI firm SenseTime and voice recognition developer iFlyTek have each introduced their own alternative services to ChatGPT, which took the world by storm after its launch in November. Alibaba owns the Post.

;

;In April, the CAC unveiled a new set of draft rules targeting ChatGPT-like services. It requires companies that provide generative AI services in China to take measures that prevent discriminatory content, false information, and content that harms personal privacy or intellectual property.

;

;Still, Beijing has expressed support for this nascent sector's development. Last month's quarterly meeting of the Politburo, the Chinese Communist Party's No 2 decision-making body, concluded that China must “create an ecosystem for innovation, but at the same time take risk prevention into account”.
